source.raw_text:
The Sandbag Duffel Row is a compound, full-body exercise that targets your back (lats, traps, rhomboids), arms (biceps, forearms), and heavily engages the core and stabilizers due to the shifting load, improving posture, grip, and functional strength through a hip-hinge movement pattern. Key muscles are the latissimus dorsi, traps, rhomboids, biceps, forearms, core, and rear deltoids, while the pattern involves hinging at the hips and pulling the bag towards the chest. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Back): Lats (Latissimus Dorsi), Traps (Trapezius), Rhomboids 
• Secondary Muscles (Arms): Biceps, Forearms (grip strength) 
• Stabilizers (Core & Posterior Chain): Transverse Abdominis, Obliques, Lower Back, Glutes, Hamstrings 
• Shoulders: Rear Deltoids [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Pattern (Bent-Over Row) 

1. Starting Position: Stand with feet hip-width apart, slight knee bend, hinge at the hips with a flat back (neutral spine), gripping the sandbag. 
2. Concentric (Pulling Phase): Engage core, pull the sandbag towards your chest by driving elbows back, squeezing shoulder blades together. 
3. Peak Contraction: Pause briefly at the top, keeping the bag close to your body. 
4. Eccentric (Lowering Phase): Slowly lower the sandbag back to the starting position with control, maintaining tension. [1, 4, 7, 8, 9]  

Key Benefits 

• Functional Strength: Mimics lifting awkward objects, improving real-world strength. 
• Core Stability: Shifting weight forces constant core engagement for balance. 
• Grip Strength: Demands intense forearm and hand activation. 
• Posture Improvement: Strengthens upper back muscles crucial for good posture. [1, 2, 5]
